questions.text: A 35 year old male presents with perineal pain and swelling after a traumatic injury during a sporting event. On examination, there is significant bruising over the scrotum and penis. Imaging confirms fluid collection in the superficial perineal space. Which of the following structures is most likely affected by the injury?
questions.explanation:
Pouches in Perineum
 

Superficial Perineal Space

Deep Perineal Space

Location

Below the perineal membrane.

Above the perineal membrane.

Boundaries
  • Superiorly: Perineal membrane
  • Inferiorly: Colles' fascia (membranous layer of superficial fascia)
  • Laterally: Ischiopubic rami
  • Posteriorly: Fusion of the perineal membrane with Colles' fascia
  • Anteriorly: Continuous with the spaces of the scrotum and penis in males, and the clitoris and anterior abdominal wall in females.
  • Superiorly: Open
  • Inferiorly: Perineal membrane
  • Laterally: Ischiopubic rami
  • Anteriorly: Gap between the perineal membrane and inferior pubic ligament.

Contents
  • In males:
    • Root of the penis (corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum)
    • Muscles (ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus, superficial transverse perinei)
    • Branches of the perineal nerve and artery
    • Ducts of the bulbourethral glands
 
  • In females:
    • Body of the clitoris (corpora cavernosa)
    • Bulbs of the vestibule
    • Muscles (ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus, superficial transverse perinei)
    • Branches of the perineal nerve and artery
    • The greater vestibular glands and their ducts
  • In males:
    • Part of the urethra
    • Muscles (sphincter urethrae in the urethral wall, deep transversus perinei) (Option A)
    • Dorsal nerve of the penis (Option C)
    • Muscular branches from the perineal nerve
    • Artery of the penis
    • Bulbourethral glands
 
  • In females:
    • Parts of the urethra and vagina
    • Muscles (sphincter urethrae in the urethral wall, deep transversus perinei, compressor urethrae, sphincter urethrovaginalis),
    • Dorsal nerve of the clitoris,
    • Muscular branches from the perineal nerve,
    • Artery of the clitoris, and no glands.

questions.text: From the muscles given below, choose the muscles forming the pelvic diaphragm. Levator ani Coccygeus Bulbospongiosus Ischiocavernosus Superficial transverse perineal muscle Deep transverse perineal muscle
questions.explanation:
Definition

Muscular partition between the true pelvis and the perineum

Components

Levator ani and coccygeus muscles on both sides and their covering fasciae

Functions

  • Support to the pelvic viscera
  • Sphincteric action on the rectum and vagina
  • Increasing intra-abdominal pressure during defecation, micturition, and parturition

Openings

1. Hiatus Urogenitalis:

  • Triangular gap between anterior fibers of the two levator ani muscles.
  • Transmits the urethra in males, and the urethra and vagina in females.

2. Hiatus Rectalis:

  • Round opening between the perineal body and the anococcygeal raphe.
  • Provides passage to the anorectal junction.

questions.text: Choose the wrong pairing of fibers of pubococcygeus with its name.
Which of the following lobes of the prostate is responsible for producing uvula vesicae?
questions.explanation:
Lobe

Location

Key Features

Anterior Lobe

In front of the urethra, connecting the two lateral lobes
  • Devoid of glandular tissue
  • Also called isthmus

Posterior Lobe

Behind the ejaculatory ducts and median lobe

Primary site of carcinoma of the prostate

Median Lobe

Behind the upper part of the urethra and in front of the ejaculatory ducts
  • Wedge-shaped
  • Common site of adenoma
  • Base produces an elevation at the apex of trigonum vesicae called uvula vesicae - A slight elevation in the mucous membrane of urinary bladder immediately above and behind the internal urethral orifice
  • Most commonly enlarged in BPH

Lateral Lobes

One on each side of the urethra
  • Separated by posterior median sulcus
  • Contains glandular tissue
  • Possible site of adenoma in old age

questions.text: A 72-year-old man visits the clinic for evaluation of urinary symptoms, including nocturia, increased urgency, and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. During the examination, a digital rectal exam reveals a smooth, enlarged prostate without any palpable nodules. The patient's PSA level is slightly elevated at 5.5 ng/mL. In which zone of the prostate does this condition primarily occur?
questions.explanation:
Prostate Zones

Description

Peripheral Zone
  • Extends posterolaterally around the gland from the apex to the base.
  • Represents the most common site in the prostate for developing prostate carcinomas.

Transitional Zone
  • Constitutes two small lobules around the prostatic urethra.
  • Represent the region where benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) primarily originates.
  • Carcinomas that originate in the transition zone have been suggested to be of lower malignant potential.

Central Zone
  • Surrounds the ejaculatory duct apparatus and makes up the majority of the prostatic base.
  • Less frequently involved in BPH or malignancy.

Anterior Fibromuscular Stroma

Rarely associated with disease

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent urination, especially at night, and difficulty initiating urination. He reports that he feels an urge to urinate but often has to wait before the stream begins. During the digital rectal exam, the physician notes a smooth, enlarged prostate. Patient has a medical history of diabetes and hyperlipidemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pathophysiology
  • Hormonal changes (increased dihydrotestosterone, DHT) contribute to prostate growth.
  • Proliferation of stromal and epithelial cells, and delayed epithelial cell death in the transitional zone.

Risk factors
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Metabolic syndrome
  • Heavy caffeine consumption
  • High dose supplemental vitamin-C
  • 1st degree relatives

Symptoms
  • Storage Symptoms:
    • Urinary frequency
    • Urgency
    • Nocturia
    • Incontinence (Urgency, stress)
  • Voiding Symptoms:
    • Hesitancy
    • Small stream
    • Intermittency
    • Terminal dribbling
    • Urinary retention


 

Diagnosis
  • Digital rectal exam (DRE) reveals enlarged prostate.
  • Urinalysis to rule out infection.
  • Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test to assess for prostate cancer.
  • Urinary flow rate tests can evaluate the severity of obstruction.
  • 24 hour voiding diary
  • Urodynamics

Complications
  • Acute urinary retention
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Bladder stones
  • Kidney damage (if untreated)

Treatment
  • Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin), 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (finasteride).
  • Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)
  • Transurethral incision of the prostate
  • Transurethral electrovaporization
  • Holmium and Thulium laser enucleation of the prostate

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the prostatic urethra is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is primarily lined by stratified squamous epithelium.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the shortest segment of the male urethra.

options.label: C
options.text: It connects the bladder to the membranous urethra and receives the ejaculatory ducts.

options.label: D
options.text: It is solely responsible for the passage of urine, with no role in the reproductive system.

questions.correct_answer: C. It connects the bladder to the membranous urethra and receives the ejaculatory ducts.
questions.explanation:
Location
  • Widest part of male urethra. (Option B)
  • Contains urethral crest, seminal colliculus, prostatic utricle and orifices of prostatic duct.
  • Extends from the bladder neck to the beginning of the membranous urethra which is approximately 3-4 cm in length. (Option C)

Histology
  • Urothelium immediately surrounded by glandular and strong tissue of the periurethral zone of the prostate. (Option A)

Functions
  • Conducts urine from the bladder to the external urethral orifice and serves as a passage for semen during ejaculation. (Option D)

Associated Structures
  • Receives the ejaculatory ducts, which deliver semen from the seminal vesicles and the vas deferens and contains the prostatic urethral orifices, which allow for the secretion of prostatic fluid.

Clinical Significance
  • Can be affected by conditions such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and prostate cancer, leading to urinary obstruction.
  • Digital rectal examination (DRE) can assess the prostate’s condition via the prostatic urethra.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly lists the segments of the male urethra in the order they occur from the bladder to the external urethral orifice?

options.label: A
options.text: Prostatic urethra → Membranous urethra → Spongy urethra

options.label: B
options.text: Spongy urethra → Membranous urethra → Prostatic urethra

options.label: C
options.text: Membranous urethra → Spongy urethra → Prostatic urethra

options.label: D
options.text: Prostatic urethra → Spongy urethra → Membranous urethra

questions.correct_answer: A. Prostatic urethra → Membranous urethra → Spongy urethra
questions.explanation:
Pre-Prostatic Urethra
  • Location: Extends inferiorly from urinary bladder and ends prior to entering the prostate gland.
  • Gross Features: It is embedded within the walls of the urinary bladder and is typically 0.5 to 1.5 cm in length.
  • Histological Features: Transitional epithelium (urothelium)

Prostatic Urethra
  • Location: Completely encompassed within the prostate gland.
  • Gross Features: This is generally the widest part of the male urethra, and contains the urethral crest, seminal colliculus, prostatic utricle, and the orifices of the prostatic ducts - typically 3.0 to 4.0 cm in length.
  • Histological Features: Urothelium immediately surrounded by the glandular and stromal tissue of the periurethral zone of the prostate.

Membranous Urethra
  • Location: Begins immediately outside of the prostate and ends just prior to entering the bulb of the penis.
  • Gross Features: Passes through the deep perineal pouch, the external urethral sphincter, and the perineal membrane.Typically 1 to 1.5 cm in length.
  • Histological Features: Pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

Spongy Urethra/Penile Urethra
  • Location: Travels the entire length of the penis via the corpus spongiosum.
  • Gross Features: Widens initially as it enters the bulb of the penis and widens again in the glans of the penis, forming the navicular fossa.Typically around 15 cm in length.
  • Histological Features: Pseudostratified columnar epithelium except for the terminal portion which is stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text: Gynaecologist is planning to do uterine artery ligation. She must be careful while performing it due to the risk of injuring which structure?

options.label: A
options.text: Ureter, as it lies anterior to uterine artery

options.label: B
options.text: Ureter, as it lies posterior to uterine artery

options.label: C
options.text: Bladder, as it lies superior to uterine artery

options.label: D
options.text: Urethra, as it lies inferior to uterine artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Ureter, as it lies posterior to uterine artery
questions.explanation:
Broad ligament

Fold of peritoneum attaching uterus to the lateral pelvic wall

Mesovarium

Attaches ovary to the posterior layer of broad ligament

Mesometrium

Part of broad ligament lying between uterine tube and ovarian ligament (Ovarian ligament: passes from lower pole of ovary to lateral angle of uterus)

Suspensory Ligament of the Ovary

  • Part of the broad ligament that stretches from the upper pole of the ovary and the infundibulum of the uterine tube to the lateral pelvic wall
  • Also known as infundibulopelvic ligament

questions.text: Match the branches of uterine arteries with their names based on the image given: 1 a) Basal artery 2 b) Spiral artery 3 c) Arcuate artery 4 d) Radial artery
questions.explanation:
A

Arcuate Artery
  • Supplies the myometrium(outer ⅓) and gives Radial artery
  • The arcuate artery around the cervix is also called the circular artery of the cervix

R

Radial Artery
  • Supplies the myometrium ( inner ⅔)
  • Gives Basal artery

B

Basal Artery
  • Present in the basal endometrium, does not get sloughed off during menstruation
  • Forms vascular layers, known as stratum vasculare

S

Spiral Artery
  • Present in the innermost layer of endometrium to get sloughed off during menstruation.
  • Spirally arranged to prevent excess bleed during menses

questions.text: A 30 year old female presented with post coital bleeding. Hysterectomy with lymph node dissection was done. Gross specimen of the uterus is shown below. Which of the following nodes group is least likely to be positive for malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Lymphatics

Region

Draining Lymph Node

Upper

Fundus and upper half of uterine body including ovary and fallopian tube

Aortic group (Pre- & Lateral aortic)

Round ligament and uterine isthmus

Superficial inguinal

Middle

Lower half of uterine body

External iliac

Lower

Cervix

Internal iliac, Sacral & Obturator group (never inguinal) 

Vagina

Upper 1/3rd

External iliac

Middle 1/3rd

Internal iliac

Lower 1/3rd

Superficial inguinal

questions.text: Angle shown in the image below in a non-gravid uterus is maintained by?
questions.explanation:
Angle of Anteversion

Description

Angle between long axis of cervix and long axis of vagina

Angle

Normal: 90°

Maintained by

Non-pregnant female: Round ligament (main) + uterosacral ligament (Option C)

Pregnant female: Round ligament only

Angle of Anteflexion

Description

Angle between long axis of uterus and long axis of cervix

Angle

Normal: 120°-170°

Maintained by

Uterosacral ligament

Mackenrodt’s Ligaments
  • Formed by condensation of parietal fascia covering the obturator internus.
  • Distal part of the ureter passes under the uterine artery within the upper part of the cardinal ligament.
  • Function: Lateral stabilization to the cervix at the level of ischial spine.

Uterosacral Ligaments
  • Formed by condensation of peritoneum.
  • They hold the cervix posteriorly at the level of the ischial spines and the uterus in Anteflexed state.

Pubocervical Fascia (Bladder Pillar)
  • Serve mainly as vascular conduit.

Extensions:

  • Rectovaginal septum: known as Fascia of Denonvilliers’
  • Pubocervical ring: encircles supravaginal part of cervix
  • Vesicovaginal septum: supports bladder and anterior vaginal wall

Round Ligament
  • Runs anterior to obturator artery and lateral to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Main ligament responsible for maintaining the uterus in Anteverted state.
  • Embryologically, it corresponds with the gubernaculum of testis.
  • In the fetus, the peritoneum continuing with the round ligament in the inguinal region is known as Canal of Nuck.

Ovarian Ligament
  • Morphologically continuous with the round ligament and is homologous to the gubernaculum of testis.
